results.name: Least number to start a run of exactly n nondecreasing values of sigma (sum of divisors, A000203).
comment: The analogous sequence based on tau = A000005 instead of sigma is A284597.
example: We have the following values of sigma for n = 1..10:
We see a run of 4 nondecreasing values starting at 1, ending at 4, therefore a(4) = 1. There is a run of 2 nondecreasing values starting at 5, ending at 6, therefore a(2) = 5.
Correspondingly, a run of length 1 corresponds to a number n such that sigma(n-1) > sigma(n) > sigma(n+1). This happens first at a(1) = 45.
mathematica: Function[s, {45}~Join~Map[Function[r, Select[s, Last@ # == r &][[1, 1]]], Range[2, Max[s[[All, -1]] ] ]]]@ Map[{#[[1, 1]], Length@ # + 1} &, DeleteCases[SplitBy[#, #[[-1]] >= 0 &], k_ /; k[[1, -1]] < 0]] &@ MapIndexed[{First@ #2, #1} &, Differences@ Array[DivisorSigma[1, #] &, 10^6]] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, May 06 2017 *)
